org.fpe4j

Class Common

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.fpe4j.Common

  • public class Common
extends java.lang.Object
    Common functions used by FF1 and FF3.
    Author:
    Kai Johnson

    • Method Detail

      • num

        protected static java.math.BigInteger num(int[] X,
                                          int radix)
        NIST SP 800-38G Algorithm 1: NUMradix(X) - Converts a string of numerals to an integer, valuing the numerals in decreasing order of significance.

        Prerequisite:
        Base, radix.

        Input:
        Numeral string, X.

        Output:
        Number, x.

        Parameters:
        X - The string of numerals to convert to a number.
        radix - The base of the numerals such that 0 <= X[i] < radix for all i.
        Returns:
        The number that the numeral string X represents in base radix when the numerals are valued in decreasing order of significance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If X is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If X is empty or has more than 4096 elements; if radix is less than 2 or greater than 65536; or if any numeral X[i] is outside the range [0..radix-1].

      • num

        protected static java.math.BigInteger num(byte[] X)
        NIST SP 800-38G Algorithm 2: NUM(X) - Converts a string of bytes to an integer, valuing the bytes as unsigned integers in decreasing order of significance.

        Input:
        Byte string, X, represented in bits.

        Output:
        Integer, x.

        Note that NIST SP 800-38G defines the algorithm in terms of bits, but we have implemented it using an array of bytes as input.

        Parameters:
        X - The string of bytes to convert to a number.
        Returns:
        The integer that a byte string X represents when the bytes are valued in decreasing order of significance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If X is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If X is empty or if X has more than 4096 elements.

      • str

        protected static int[] str(java.math.BigInteger x,
                           int radix,
                           int m)
        NIST SP 800-38G Algorithm 3: STRmradix(x) - Converts an integer to an array of numerals of a given radix.

        Prerequisites:
        Base, radix;
        String length, m.

        Input:
        Integer, x, such that 0 <= x < radixm.

        Output:
        Numeral string, X.

        Parameters:
        x - The integer to convert to a string of numerals.
        radix - The base of the numerals such that 0 <= X[i] < radix for all i.
        m - The length of the string of numerals.
        Returns:
        Given a nonnegative integer x less than radixm, the representation of x as a string of m numerals in base radix, in decreasing order of significance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If x is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If m is not within the range [1..4096]; if radix is not within the range [2..65536]; or if x is not within the range [0..radixm].

      • rev

        protected static int[] rev(int[] X)
        NIST SP 800-38G Algorithm 4: REV(X) - Reverse a string of numerals.

        Input:
        Numeral string, X.

        Output:
        Numeral string, Y.

        Parameters:
        X - The numeral string to reverse.
        Returns:
        Given a numeral string, X, the numeral string that consists of the numerals of X in reverse order.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If X is null.

      • revb

        protected static byte[] revb(byte[] X)
        NIST SP 800-38G Algorithm 5: REVB(X) - Reverse an array of bytes.

        Input:
        Byte string, X, represented in bits.

        Output:
        Byte string, Y, represented in bits.

        Note that although NIST SP 800-38G refers to strings of individually addressable bits, this is not a common feature of programming languages. In this implementation, we use arrays of bytes to represent the data type.

        Parameters:
        X - The bit string (i.e. array of bytes) to reverse.
        Returns:
        Given a byte string, X, the byte string that consists of the bytes of X in reverse order.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If X is null.

      • xor

        protected static byte[] xor(byte[] X,
                            byte[] Y)
        Returns an array of bytes whose values are X[i] ^ Y[i].

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: X ⊕ Y

        Parameters:
        X - The first bit string (i.e. array of bytes).
        Y - The second bit string (i.e. array of bytes).
        Returns:
        The bitwise addition, modulo 2, of two bit strings of equal length.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If either X or Y is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if X or Y is empty; if X or Y has more than 4096 elements; or if X.length != Y.length.

      • log2

        protected static double log2(int x)
        Returns the base 2 logarithm of x.

        We have renamed this function "log2(x)" to avoid confusion with the natural log function.

        NIST SP 800-38G describes the input as a "real" number, but only provides integer values as input, so we have defined the input as an int to avoid unnecessary type conversion.

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: LOG(x)

        Parameters:
        x - The real number > 0.
        Returns:
        The base 2 logarithm of the real number x > 0.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If x is not greater than 0.

      • floor

        protected static int floor(double x)
        Returns the largest integer value that is less than or equal to x.

        In NIST SP 800-38G, this function is used to round the result of integer division. However, in Java, the result of integer division is rounded down to an integer. To use the function on the result of integer division, one of the integers must first be converted to a double to produce a fractional result.

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: ⌊x⌋

        Parameters:
        x - The real number.
        Returns:
        The greatest integer that does not exceed the real number x.

      • floor

        protected static int floor(int x)
        Alternate form of the floor function with an integer argument to trap incorrect usage.
        Parameters:
        x - An integer.
        Returns:
        Throws an IllegalArgumentException.

      • ceiling

        protected static int ceiling(double x)
        Returns the smallest integer value that is greater than or equal to x.

        In NIST SP 800-38G, this function is used to round the result of integer division. However, in Java, the result of integer division is rounded down to an integer. To use the function on the result of integer division, one of the integers must first be converted to a double to produce a fractional result.

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: ⌈x⌉

        Parameters:
        x - The real number.
        Returns:
        The least integer that is not less than the real number x.

      • ceiling

        protected static int ceiling(int x)
        Alternate form of the ceiling function with an integer argument to trap incorrect usage.
        Parameters:
        x - An integer.
        Returns:
        Throws an IllegalArgumentException.

      • mod

        protected static int mod(int x,
                         int m)
        Given a real number x and a positive integer m, returns the remainder of x modulo m, denoted by x mod m, which is x - m * floor(x/m).

        NIST SP 800-38G describes the input as a "real" number, but provides only integer values as input. We have defined the input as an int to avoid unnecessary type conversion.

        NIST SP 800-38G Notation: MOD(x)

        Parameters:
        x - The "real" number (defined as an int to avoid unnecessary type conversion).
        m - The modulus.
        Returns:
        The nonnegative remainder of the integer x modulo the positive integer m.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException - If m is less than 1.

      • mod

        protected static java.math.BigInteger mod(java.math.BigInteger x,
                                          java.math.BigInteger m)
        Given a real number x and a positive integer m, returns the remainder of x modulo m, denoted by x mod m, which is x - m * floor(x/m).

        NIST SP 800-38G describes the input as a "real" number, but provides only integer values as input. We have defined the input as a BigInteger to avoid unnecessary type conversion.

        NIST SP 800-38G Notation: MOD(x)

        Parameters:
        x - The "real" number (defined as a BigInteger to avoid unnecessary type conversion).
        m - The modulus.
        Returns:
        The nonnegative remainder of the integer x modulo the positive integer m.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException - If m is less than 1.

      • bytestring

        protected static byte[] bytestring(int x,
                                   int s)
        Expands x into an array of bytes of length s.

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: [x]s

        Parameters:
        x - The integer to convert to an array of bytes.
        s - The length of the output in bytes.
        Returns:
        Given a nonnegative integer x less than 256s , the representation of x as a string of s bytes.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If s is not within the range [1..4096]; if x is negative; or if x is greater than 256s.

      • bytestring

        protected static byte[] bytestring(java.math.BigInteger x,
                                   int s)
        Expands x into an array of bytes of length s.

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: [x]s

        Parameters:
        x - The integer to convert to an array of bytes.
        s - The length of the output in bytes.
        Returns:
        Given a nonnegative integer x less than 256s , the representation of x as a string of s bytes.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If s is not within the range [1..4096]; if x is negative; or if x is greater than 256s.

      • bitstring

        protected static byte[] bitstring(boolean bit,
                                  int s)
                           throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Returns an array of bits of length s filled with either 0s or 1s.

        Note that although NIST SP 800-38G refers to strings of individually addressable bits, this is not a common feature of programming languages. In this implementation, we use arrays of bytes to represent the data type.

        The implementations of FF1 and FF3 sometimes use inline constants in place of this bitstring function.

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: 0s or 1s

        Parameters:
        bit - The bit value with which to fill the output; false = 0, true = 1
        s - The length of the output in bits (not bytes!)
        Returns:
        The bit string that consists of s consecutive 'bit' bits.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If s <= 0 or if s is not a multiple of 8.

      • concatenate

        protected static int[] concatenate(int[] X,
                                   int[] Y)
        Concatenates two arrays of integers.

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: X || Y

        Parameters:
        X - The first numeral string.
        Y - The second numeral string.
        Returns:
        The concatenation of numeral strings X and Y.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If X or Y is null.

      • concatenate

        protected static byte[] concatenate(byte[] X,
                                    byte[] Y)
        Concatenates two arrays of bytes

        NIST SP 800-38G notation: X || Y

        Parameters:
        X - The first numeral string.
        Y - The second numeral string.
        Returns:
        The concatenation of numeral strings X and Y.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If X or Y is null.

      • unsignedByteArrayToString

        protected static java.lang.String unsignedByteArrayToString(byte[] X)
        Converts an array of bytes to a string, treating the bytes as unsigned integers, with commas and spaces separating the byte values.
        Parameters:
        X - The array of bytes.
        Returns:
        The string with commas and spaces separating the elements of X interpreted as unsigned values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If X is null.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
